items.description: Formalize the problem statement with precise definitions: define the Beatty sequence B_r = (floor(n*r))_{n>=1} for real r > 0, define 'homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence' as a subsequence (a_{n_k}) satisfying c_1*a_{n_k} + c_2*a_{n_{k+1}} + ... + c_d*a_{n_{k+d-1}} = 0 for all k with fixed integer coefficients not all zero, and clarify the parameter space (rational r, quadratic irrational r, higher-degree algebraic r, transcendental r).
items.acceptance_criteria: A LaTeX or Markdown document in results/ containing: (1) rigorous definition of floor(n*r) as a Beatty sequence, (2) formal definition of homogeneous linear recurrence of order d with constant coefficients, (3) precise statement of what 'contains a homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence' means (specifying whether n_k must be arithmetic, arbitrary, etc.), (4) taxonomy of the parameter space for r into at least 4 classes (rational, quadratic irrational, algebraic of degree >= 3, transcendental).
items.notes: Created results/problem_formalization.md with rigorous definitions of Beatty sequences, homogeneous linear recurrence, subsequence containment, and 4-class taxonomy of r.

items.description: Conduct web-based literature review on Beatty sequences, Sturmian words, and their recurrence properties. Search for papers by Fraenkel, Kimberling, Shallit, Cassaigne, Durand, Allouche, and others on the combinatorial and recurrence structure of floor(n*r).
items.acceptance_criteria: A file sources.bib in the repo root containing at least 12 relevant BibTeX entries covering: (a) Beatty's original theorem and Rayleigh's theorem, (b) Sturmian word theory (Morse-Hedlund, Coven-Hedlund), (c) linear recurrence in Sturmian subshifts (Cassaigne, Durand), (d) Ostrowski numeration and automatic sequences for quadratic irrationals (Shallit, Hieronymi-Terry), (e) Skolem-Mahler-Lech theorem, (f) three-distance theorem / Steinhaus conjecture. Each entry must have title, author, year, and publication venue.
items.notes: Created sources.bib with 28 BibTeX entries covering Beatty (1926), Rayleigh, Morse-Hedlund, Coven-Hedlund, Durand, Cassaigne, Allouche-Shallit, Schaeffer-Shallit-Zorcic, Skolem-Mahler-Lech, Sos three-distance, Berlekamp-Massey, and more.

items.description: Analyze the rational case r = p/q in detail. When r is rational, floor(n*r) is eventually periodic (in fact, the first differences floor((n+1)*r) - floor(n*r) are periodic with period q). Determine which homogeneous linear recurrences are satisfied by subsequences of floor(n*p/q).
items.acceptance_criteria: A proof or rigorous argument showing: (1) for rational r = p/q, the sequence floor(n*r) satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence of order at most q (specifically a_{n+q} - a_n = p for all n, which rearranges to homogeneous form a_{n+2q} - 2*a_{n+q} + a_n = 0), (2) every subsequence indexed by an arithmetic progression also satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence, (3) explicit construction of the minimal-order recurrence for at least 3 example rationals (e.g., r=3/2, r=5/3, r=7/4).
items.notes: Created results/rational_case_analysis.md. Proved: a_{n+q}-a_n=p for r=p/q, yielding order-2q homogeneous recurrence. Computed minimal recurrences for r=3/2,5/3,7/4. Verified numerically for 1000 terms.

items.description: Study the key connection between Sturmian words and Beatty sequences: the first-difference sequence Delta_r(n) = floor((n+1)*r) - floor(n*r) is a Sturmian word when r is irrational. Investigate when Sturmian words are linearly recurrent (uniformly recurrent with linear gap bounds) using Durand's characterization.
items.acceptance_criteria: A document containing: (1) proof that Delta_r is Sturmian iff r is irrational, (2) statement and proof sketch of Durand's theorem that a Sturmian word is linearly recurrent iff the partial quotients in the continued fraction of r are bounded, (3) connection to Lagrange's theorem (bounded partial quotients iff r is a quadratic irrational), (4) explicit analysis of what 'linearly recurrent' means for the Sturmian word vs. for subsequences of floor(n*r) itself.
items.notes: Created results/sturmian_analysis.md. Proved Delta_r is Sturmian iff r irrational. Stated Durand theorem on linear recurrence of Sturmian words iff bounded partial quotients. Connected to Lagrange theorem.

items.description: Review the Skolem-Mahler-Lech theorem and its implications for zero sets of linear recurrence sequences, and study how the three-distance theorem constrains the gap structure of Beatty sequences. Research the Schaeffer-Shallit decidability results for quadratic Beatty sequences.
items.acceptance_criteria: A document containing: (1) precise statement of Skolem-Mahler-Lech and its relevance to identifying which subsequences of a linearly recurrent sequence can themselves be linearly recurrent, (2) statement of the three-distance theorem for rotations on the circle and its connection to gap structure in floor(n*r), (3) summary of Schaeffer-Shallit-Zorcic (2024) decidability results for Beatty sequences of quadratic irrationals via Ostrowski numeration, (4) at least 3 papers cited from sources.bib for each sub-topic.
items.notes: Created results/skolem_three_distance.md. Stated Skolem-Mahler-Lech, three-distance theorem, and Schaeffer-Shallit-Zorcic decidability results. All properly cited.

items.description: Investigate the distinction between (a) the Sturmian word associated with r being linearly recurrent (a property of the symbolic dynamics) and (b) the integer-valued Beatty sequence floor(n*r) containing a subsequence that satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence relation. Clarify whether these are equivalent, one implies the other, or they are independent.
items.acceptance_criteria: A rigorous analysis document with: (1) formal definitions distinguishing the two notions, (2) at least one direction of implication proved or refuted with a counterexample, (3) identification of the exact gap: does 'linearly recurrent Sturmian word' imply or follow from 'floor(n*r) has a homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence'?, (4) discussion of whether every floor sequence (even for non-quadratic irrationals or transcendentals) trivially contains a linearly recurrent subsequence (e.g., constant subsequences, or subsequences along arithmetic progressions where the recurrence degenerates).
items.notes: Created results/two_notions_analysis.md. Proved the two notions (Sturmian linear recurrence vs algebraic linear recurrence) are independent. Key result: for irrational r, no AP subsequence of floor(nr) satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence.

items.description: Implement a Python module that computes the Beatty sequence floor(n*r) for arbitrary real r (using mpmath or sympy for exact arithmetic with algebraic numbers) and extracts subsequences. Support rational, quadratic irrational (e.g., golden ratio, sqrt(2), sqrt(3)), and transcendental (e.g., pi, e) inputs.
items.acceptance_criteria: A Python file src/beatty.py that: (1) computes floor(n*r) for n=1..N with configurable precision for irrational r, (2) supports exact rational arithmetic for rational r, (3) extracts subsequences along arithmetic progressions {a + kd : k >= 0}, (4) extracts subsequences along arbitrary index sets, (5) passes unit tests for r=golden_ratio, r=sqrt(2), r=3/2, r=pi with N=10000 matching known OEIS values (A001950, A001951, A001952, etc.).
items.notes: src/beatty.py: Beatty seq computation with exact rational and high-precision irrational support. All OEIS tests pass.

items.description: Implement a linear recurrence detector: given a finite sequence (a_1, ..., a_N), determine whether it satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence of order <= d_max, and if so find the minimal such recurrence. Use the Berlekamp-Massey algorithm or matrix-based methods.
items.acceptance_criteria: A Python file src/recurrence_detector.py that: (1) implements Berlekamp-Massey or an equivalent algorithm for finding minimal homogeneous linear recurrences, (2) given a sequence of length N, returns the minimal-order homogeneous linear recurrence (coefficients and order) or reports that none of order <= d_max exists, (3) handles exact integer arithmetic (no floating-point errors), (4) passes tests on known recurrence sequences: Fibonacci (order 2), tribonacci (order 3), powers of 2 (order 1 homogeneous: a_{n+1} = 2*a_n), (5) correctly identifies that random sequences and Beatty sequences of pi do not satisfy low-order recurrences.
items.notes: src/recurrence_detector.py: BM algorithm with modular screening + exact verification. N/10 order cap to avoid quasi-periodic false positives.

items.description: Build a systematic search framework that, given r, enumerates candidate subsequences of floor(n*r) and tests each for homogeneous linear recurrence. Search over: (a) arithmetic progressions with offset a and common difference d for small a,d, (b) subsequences indexed by floor(n*s) for various s (nested Beatty), (c) greedy/adaptive index selection.
items.acceptance_criteria: A Python file src/subsequence_search.py that: (1) enumerates arithmetic progression subsequences for a in {0,...,A_max}, d in {1,...,D_max}, (2) for each candidate subsequence of length >= 50, runs the recurrence detector from item_008, (3) logs all discovered recurrences with their parameters (r, subsequence type, recurrence order, coefficients), (4) runs to completion for r in {3/2, 5/3, golden_ratio, sqrt(2), sqrt(3), sqrt(5), pi, e} with A_max=20, D_max=20, producing a summary CSV in results/.
items.notes: src/subsequence_search.py: AP subsequence search. Results in results/subsequence_search.csv. Rationals: all YES, irrationals: all NO.

items.description: Establish baseline metrics: for each tested r, record (a) whether any homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence was found, (b) the minimal order of such a recurrence, (c) the type of subsequence index set (arithmetic progression, nested Beatty, other), (d) the continued fraction expansion of r (first 50 partial quotients).
items.acceptance_criteria: A CSV file results/baseline_metrics.csv with columns [r_value, r_type, cf_partial_quotients_50, recurrence_found, min_recurrence_order, recurrence_coefficients, subsequence_type, subsequence_params] populated for at least 20 distinct values of r spanning all 4 classes (rational, quadratic irrational, higher algebraic, transcendental), with at least 5 values per class.
items.notes: results/baseline_metrics.csv: 29 values tested (13 rational, 7 quad irr, 6 higher alg, 3 transcendental). Clean dichotomy: rational iff recurrence exists.

items.description: Prove the rational case completely: for r = p/q rational (in lowest terms, p,q > 0), show that floor(n*r) itself (the full sequence) satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence of order 2q, and characterize the minimal order. Prove that the entire sequence is a quasi-polynomial (piecewise linear function of n modulo q).
items.acceptance_criteria: A rigorous proof document (LaTeX or Markdown in results/) containing: (1) proof that a_{n+q} = a_n + p for all n >= 1 when r = p/q, hence a_{n+2q} - 2a_{n+q} + a_n = 0, (2) proof that the minimal homogeneous recurrence order divides 2q and determination of the exact minimal order, (3) explicit characteristic polynomial and its roots, (4) verification that the computational results from item_010 match the theoretical predictions for all tested rationals.
items.notes: results/rational_case_proof.md: Complete proof that minimal order is q+1 with characteristic polynomial (x-1)(x^q-1). Includes fundamental shift identity, minimality proof, AP subsequence theorem, explicit examples for r=3/2,5/3,7/4, cyclotomic analysis, and computational verification against all 13 tested rationals.

items.description: Prove the quadratic irrational case: for r a quadratic irrational, investigate whether floor(n*r) contains a non-trivial homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence. Use the connection to Ostrowski representations and the morphic/automatic structure of the Sturmian word. The key conjecture to resolve: for quadratic irrational r, subsequences of floor(n*r) along arithmetic progressions satisfy eventual quasi-linear growth, not exact linear recurrence, unless the recurrence is trivially derived from the quasi-linear structure.
items.acceptance_criteria: A proof or strong partial result document containing: (1) analysis of floor(n*r) for r = golden ratio along arithmetic progressions {a + kd}, showing whether any such subsequence satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence, (2) extension to general quadratic irrationals (r = (a + sqrt(D))/b), (3) either a proof that non-trivial homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequences exist (with explicit construction) or a proof that they do not (with lower bounds on recurrence violation), (4) connection to the Ostrowski representation and why the morphic structure does or does not force linear recurrence.
items.notes: results/irrational_case_proof.md: Complete proof that NO AP subsequence of floor(nr) satisfies a homogeneous linear recurrence for ANY irrational r. Proof uses growth analysis, rationality constraint on asymptotic slope, and Weyl equidistribution. Includes Ostrowski/morphic analysis for quadratic irrationals, extension to polynomial/exponential index sets, and computational verification (0/16 irrationals positive).

items.description: Analyze the transcendental case and higher-degree algebraic case: investigate whether the continued fraction structure (unbounded partial quotients for non-quadratic irrationals, Roth's theorem constraints for algebraic numbers, vs. possible Liouville-type behavior for transcendentals) determines existence of linearly recurrent subsequences. Formulate and test a precise conjecture linking Diophantine approximation properties of r to the existence of such subsequences.
items.acceptance_criteria: A document containing: (1) precise conjecture statement linking properties of r (rationality, bounded vs unbounded CF, irrationality measure) to existence of homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequences in floor(n*r), (2) proof or computational evidence for at least 3 non-quadratic algebraic irrationals (e.g., cube root of 2, cube root of 3), (3) analysis for at least 3 transcendentals (pi, e, Liouville's constant), (4) discussion of whether Roth's theorem (irrationality measure = 2 for algebraics) vs. unbounded irrationality measure for some transcendentals creates a meaningful distinction, (5) results compared against literature found in Phase 1.
items.notes: results/transcendental_algebraic_analysis.md: Proves the characterization is a theorem (not just conjecture). Analyzes 6 algebraic degree>=3 numbers (cbrt(2),cbrt(3),cbrt(5),2^{1/4},3^{1/4},5^{1/4}) and 3 transcendentals (pi,e,ln2). Shows Roth's theorem, CF structure, and algebraic degree create NO distinction -- only rationality matters. Discusses pi approximation by 355/113 and Liouville numbers.

items.description: Prove the main characterization theorem (or the strongest partial result achievable): Synthesize findings from items 011-013 into a unified theorem characterizing the set of r for which floor(n*r) contains a homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence. The expected answer based on preliminary analysis: r rational => yes (the full sequence is linearly recurrent); r irrational => investigate whether the answer is 'never,' 'only for quadratic irrationals,' or 'always (with trivial subsequences).'
items.acceptance_criteria: A proof document containing: (1) complete theorem statement of the form 'The sequence floor(n*r) contains a non-trivial homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence if and only if [characterization of r]', (2) proof of the 'if' direction with explicit construction, (3) proof of the 'only if' direction (or identification of the exact obstruction), (4) precise definition of 'non-trivial' used (excluding, e.g., constant subsequences or length-1 subsequences), (5) statement of any open cases with concrete conjectures. Proof must be logically complete or clearly identify gaps.
items.notes: results/main_characterization.md: Complete theorem: r rational <=> floor(nr) satisfies homogeneous linear recurrence <=> some AP subsequence satisfies one. Three-way equivalence (i)<=>(ii)<=>(iii) fully proved. Includes extensions to polynomial/exponential index sets, completeness table, comparison with prior work, and confidence assessment (HIGH). Novel contribution: complete clean characterization with uniform proof across all irrationals.

items.description: Handle edge cases and boundary phenomena: (a) r = 1 (floor(n) = n, which trivially satisfies a_{n+2} - 2a_{n+1} + a_n = 0), (b) r close to rational (e.g., r = p/q + epsilon for small epsilon — when does the recurrence 'break'?), (c) r = 0 (degenerate: floor(0) = 0 for all n), (d) negative r, (e) r between 0 and 1 (many zeros in the Beatty sequence).
items.acceptance_criteria: A document containing rigorous treatment of: (1) r = 0 and r = 1 as trivial cases, (2) analysis of r in (0,1) showing the sequence has long runs of repeated values and characterizing recurrence, (3) perturbation analysis: for r = p/q + epsilon, quantify how the recurrence from the rational case deteriorates as epsilon grows (compute recurrence residual as a function of epsilon and n), (4) treatment of negative r via floor(n*r) = -ceiling(n*|r|) and reduction to positive case, (5) at least 2 computed examples per edge case.
items.notes: results/edge_cases.md: Rigorous treatment of r=0 (zero sequence, order 1), r=1 (identity, order 2), r in (0,1) rational (still recurrent, examples r=1/2,1/3,2/5) and irrational, negative r (reduction via -ceil), positive integers, large-denominator rationals (355/113 vs pi), and perturbation analysis showing sharp discontinuous transition at rational/irrational boundary. Multiple computed examples per case.

items.description: Large-scale computational verification: run the subsequence search framework (item_009) on an expanded set of 100+ values of r, including: (a) rationals p/q for all q <= 20, (b) quadratic irrationals (a+sqrt(D))/b for D in {2,3,5,6,7,8,10,...,50}, (c) algebraic numbers of degree 3-6 (cube roots, quartic roots, roots of specific polynomials), (d) well-known transcendentals and their multiples. Increase search depth to A_max=50, D_max=50.
items.acceptance_criteria: A results file results/large_scale_search.csv with: (1) at least 100 rows, one per tested r, (2) columns for r, r_type, cf_data, recurrence_found (bool), recurrence_order, recurrence_coefficients, subsequence_description, (3) no false positives (every reported recurrence verified to hold for at least 10000 terms), (4) summary statistics: fraction of each r-type class where recurrence was found, (5) runtime and precision metadata.

items.description: Validate theoretical predictions against computational results: for every r tested in item_016, check whether the main theorem from item_014 correctly predicts the experimental outcome. Identify any discrepancies and investigate.
items.acceptance_criteria: A validation report results/theorem_validation.md containing: (1) contingency table (theorem predicts yes/no vs. experiment finds yes/no) with counts, (2) 100% agreement for rational r (theorem and experiment both say yes), (3) analysis of any disagreements with investigation of cause (numerical precision, insufficient search depth, or genuine counterexample to the theorem), (4) for any genuine discrepancies, a revised conjecture or identification of the gap in the proof.

items.description: Test the sensitivity of results to the definition of 'homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence': (a) vary the maximum allowed recurrence order d_max from 2 to 50, (b) test whether allowing inhomogeneous recurrences (with a constant term) changes the characterization, (c) test whether restricting to arithmetic-progression-indexed subsequences vs. arbitrary subsequences changes the answer.
items.acceptance_criteria: A results file results/sensitivity_analysis.csv and accompanying analysis document results/sensitivity_analysis.md containing: (1) for at least 20 representative r values, results with d_max in {2, 5, 10, 20, 50}, (2) comparison of homogeneous vs. inhomogeneous recurrence detection, (3) comparison of arithmetic-progression-only vs. all-subsequences search, (4) clear statement of which definition choices affect the characterization theorem and which do not, (5) recommendation for the 'canonical' problem formulation.

items.description: Reproduce and extend key results from the literature: (a) verify Durand's characterization that Sturmian words are linearly recurrent iff partial quotients are bounded, by computing recurrence constants for Sturmian words with known CF expansions, (b) verify Schaeffer-Shallit decidability for specific quadratic irrational Beatty sequences, (c) compare our characterization against the taxonomy of morphic/automatic sequences from Allouche-Shallit.
items.acceptance_criteria: A document results/literature_comparison.md containing: (1) reproduction of Durand's result for at least 5 quadratic irrationals and 5 non-quadratic irrationals, with computed recurrence constants, (2) comparison with at least 5 specific results from papers cited in sources.bib, (3) explicit statement of how our main theorem relates to / extends / is consistent with each cited result, (4) identification of any novel contributions beyond existing literature.

items.description: Write a complete, self-contained proof document for the main characterization theorem, incorporating all results from Phases 1-4. Structure as: (1) Introduction and motivation, (2) Definitions and notation, (3) Main theorem statement, (4) Proof of the rational case, (5) Proof of the irrational case (or strongest partial result), (6) Edge cases, (7) Computational verification summary.
items.acceptance_criteria: A LaTeX or Markdown file results/main_proof.md (or .tex) containing: (1) all sections listed above, (2) every claim either proved, cited to a source in sources.bib, or explicitly marked as a conjecture, (3) no logical gaps (every implication justified), (4) at least 2000 words of mathematical exposition, (5) all notation defined before first use, (6) theorem numbered and cross-referenced consistently.

items.description: Create visualizations: (a) plot floor(n*r) for representative r values showing recurrent vs. non-recurrent behavior, (b) plot recurrence residuals (how far a candidate recurrence misses) as a function of n for various r, (c) heatmap of recurrence detection results across the (r, d_max) parameter space.
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 4 publication-quality figures saved in figures/ as PNG or PDF: (1) figure showing floor(n*r) and an identified linearly recurrent subsequence for a rational r, (2) figure showing recurrence residuals for a quadratic irrational r, (3) heatmap of recurrence_found across r-values and d_max values, (4) figure showing continued fraction partial quotients vs. recurrence detection success. Each figure must have axis labels, title, and legend.

items.description: Write a research summary document covering: (1) problem statement and motivation, (2) main results, (3) methodology, (4) key findings, (5) comparison with prior work, (6) open questions and future directions.
items.acceptance_criteria: A file results/research_summary.md containing: (1) abstract (150-300 words), (2) all 6 sections listed, (3) bibliography section referencing sources.bib with at least 10 citations, (4) explicit list of open questions arising from the research, (5) clear statement of the novel contribution (what is new vs. what was previously known), (6) total length at least 3000 words.

items.description: Create a self-assessment checklist verifying completeness: confirm that all code runs without errors, all proofs are logically complete (or gaps identified), all experimental results are reproducible, sources.bib is complete, and the main theorem is stated precisely.
items.acceptance_criteria: A file results/self_assessment.md containing: (1) checklist of all 22 preceding items with pass/fail/partial status, (2) for any 'partial' or 'fail' items, description of what remains and why, (3) confirmation that python src/*.py files run without errors on a fresh environment, (4) confirmation that sources.bib parses as valid BibTeX, (5) final confidence level (high/medium/low) in the main theorem with justification.
